reporting-org.narrative: United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs

title.narrative: Responding to drinking water and sanitation needs along with improving hygiene practices in parallel with COVID-19 awareness in the most vulnerable camps in Idlib and Aleppo. in addition, focusing on sustainable solutions to supply safe drinking water in the targeted camps.

description.narrative:
1. The project is designed to meet WASH gabs needs considering the priorities interventions under SCHF 3rd reserve allocation 2021, where the proposed project is focusing on upgrading camps water systems by establishment of two water system operated by solar power, the first water system will be established in Susian-CP001034 in Aleppo governate Susian community reaching 4.060 IDPs in Susian camp, the second water system will be established in Jabal Alshekh Bahr -CP001938 camp, connecting Jabal Alshekh Bahr and Rahma 1 (Sheikh Bahr)- CP001209 camps with water system operating by solar power reaching 4.000 IDPs. In addition, implementing sewage network for two camps in Aleppo Al Bab sub-district, Susian-CP001034 amp Al Tareek Al Azrak- CP001035 reaching 5.743 IDPs. In addition, under the proposed project, water trucking activates with will be implemented for the camps that cannot be linked with water system for duration of seven months which are: 1. Al Tareek Al Azrak CP001035. 2. Bhorta CP001968. 3. Al-Naeemiia- CP000544. 4. Al Kalamoun CP000687. 5. Al Amal(Haranbush) CP001939. 6. Murin Caps CP000690. 7. Tokan camp CP000599. Note off, the camps targeted with water system rehabilitation will be supported for only three months with water trucking till completing the establishment process of the water system. In addition, water capita per person will be 40 liters during summer, and 35 liters per day in winter. Same as camps targeted with implementing of sewage network will be supported for only three months with septic tanks desludging till completing and linking the HHs to the implemented sewage network. Nevertheless, the following camps will be supported with septic tank desludging for a duration of seven months, where these camps cannot be linked to any near sewage network nor implementing sewage network in them: 1. Al Amal(Haranbush)- CP001939. 2. Bhorta- CP001968. 3. Al Kalamoun- CP000687. 4. Al-Naeemiia- CP000544. 5. Jabal Alshekh Bahr - CP001938. 6. Murin Caps- CP000690. 7. Tokan camp- CP000599. Moreover, the targeted camps will be supported with water tanks (In total 35 water tanks with a capacity of 2000 liters and 135 water tanks with a capacity of 1000 liters) and garbage bins (540). SWM activity will be conducted bi-daily basis.
The Framework aims to ensure that key stakeholders’ needs, priorities, and feedback are better heard and taken into account by BINAA in the design, implementation, assessment, and evaluation of programs for sustainable transformation. In this context, the Framework′s key objectives are to enhance transparency, good governance, and accountability across BINAA’s operations, and ultimately to improve the quality and accessibility of services delivered to affected people. Project level: improving the design and quality of beneficiary participation and feedback processes promoting meaningful project target group engagement throughout the project cycle stronger integration of feedback processes in project monitoring and evaluation systems and, increased attention to the development and implementation of tailored capacity-building programs enabling project target groups and other key stakeholders to sustainably engage in and manage participation and feedback processes.
To ensure gender-sensitive response, special attention will be paid to the needs of vulnerable groups of women and girls, such as female-headed households, pregnant and lactating women, women with disabilities, elderly women, adolescent girls, and children. BINAA will carry out consulting meetings with women and girls to evaluate their priorities needs to ensure that program strategies mitigate the exposure to risk. At each stage of the response, the BINAA team will facilitate a gender balance as far as possible, with a minimum percentage of the team and the beneficiaries being female.
